THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES   

A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

2. 
The state of Uttarakhand, separated from Uttar Pradesh in 2000, is one of the new and 
relatively  less-developed  Indian  states,  and,  as  a  result,  is  classified  as  a  “special  category” 
state. It is located on the northern boundary of India, and shares international borders with the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  and  Nepal.  It  has  a  total  land  area  of  53,483  square  kilometers. 
Over  90%  of  the  state’s  terrain  is  hilly  and  62%  is  forested,  limiting  the  availability  of  land  for 
agriculture. The state’s population is 8.48 million (2001). The literacy rate (83%) is much higher 
than  the  national  average  while  health  indicators  lag  behind  the  average  national  health 
indicators. About 25% (or 2.29 million) of the state’s population live in 63 urban areas. Although 
the  current  urbanization  rate  is  less  than  the  national  average  (28%),  the  urban  growth  rate 
during  1991–2001  was  more  than  1.5  times  the  growth  rate  of  the  state’s  total  population. 
According to official estimates, this rate will be sustained, and by the year 2026 over 37% of the 
Uttarakhand  population  will  live  in  urban  areas,  making  it  the  seventh-most  urbanized  state  in 
India.  
 
3. 
While  Uttarakhand  suffers  from  growth  constraints  and  limitations  in  agriculture  as  a 
result of its hilly terrain and high forest coverage, these natural assets, combined with cultural 
and  religious  heritage,  offer  immense  opportunities  for  tourism  development.  The  state  has  a 
rich  cultural  and  natural  landscape,  a  wealth  of  major  shrines  and  spiritual  centers,  and  the 
sources  of  the  Ganga  and  Yamuna  rivers,  which  are  major  tourist  attractions.  Tourism  is 
currently  the  mainstay  of  the  economy  and  a  major  source  of  employment.  In  addition  to  its 
tourism potential, the state has a bright outlook for industrial growth owing to its relatively good 
connectivity  to  other  parts  of  India  and  an  active  pursuit  of  industrial  policy,  and  fiscal  and 
regulatory incentives to attract industry to Uttarakhand. The relative importance of tourism and 
industry  to  the  economy  are  reflected  in  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  indicators  which 
show that during the period 1999–2004, services (including tourism) accounted for over 40% of 
the state’s GDP; industry accounted for 26% and agriculture 34%. While the current contribution 
of  agriculture  to  the  state’s  economy  has  been  larger  than  that  of  industry,  the  annual  growth 
rates of industry have been much higher than the agricultural growth rates.   
 
4.

in the state’s economic transformation. The evidence shows that cities and towns in the plains in

infrastructure  and  services, 
including  water  supply,  sanitation,  drainage,  solid-waste

6. 
Only  20  towns  have  a  centralized  piped  sewer  system  with  coverage  levels  ranging 
between  30%  and  75%.  Of  these  towns  served  by  piped  sewers,  only  two  have  a  sewerage 
treatment  facility.  Most  waste  water  is  co-disposed  with  storm  water  and  thence  into  natural 
water  courses,  presenting  severe  environmental  and  health  risk.  Less  than  50%  of  the  solid 
waste  generated  is  collected.  The  solid  waste  collected  is  generally  disposed  to  open  land, 
drains,  and  hill  slopes  in  the  absence  of  sanitary  landfill  sites.  Solid-waste  equipment  and 
vehicles  are  inadequate.  The  problem  is  compounded  during  the  tourist  season  when  the 
amount of solid waste significantly increases.   
 
 7. 
Urban roads are in poor condition; road networks and parking spaces are insufficient to 
meet the demands of current and future traffic volumes, given that traffic volumes have doubled 
in  the  last  10  years  and  are  projected  to  do  so  again  in  the  next  10  years.  Narrow  roads, 
coupled with poor traffic management, lead to congestion with subsequent inefficiency in urban 
mobility,  air  pollution,  and  risk  to  public  safety.  Due  to  favorable  topography,  the  incidence  of 
flooding is generally minimal, with the exception of some towns which have localized problems.  
 

2. 

Urban Governance, Management, Service Delivery, and Finance 

Urban  Governance,  Management,  and  Service  Delivery.  The  low  performance  in 
8. 
infrastructure  development  and  service  delivery  in  the  urban  centers  of  Uttarakhand  largely 
stems  from  inadequate  urban  institutional,  financial,  and  service-delivery  frameworks  and 
capacities.  Primary  responsibility  for  providing  urban  infrastructure  and  services  (except  for 
water  supply  and  sewerage),  including  on-site  sanitation,  solid-waste  management,  drainage, 
road maintenance, street lighting, and slum improvement, lies with urban local bodies (ULBs). 
However,  ULBs  cannot  perform  their  duties  effectively  as  they  lack  required  organizational 
capacities  and  operational  and  management  skills.  More  importantly,  financial  resources 
obtained through urban-based taxes and user charges are insufficient to fund the tasks of urban 
service delivery. 
 
9. 
Water supply and sewerage (WSS) service provision is the responsibility of state water 
utilities, i.e., Uttarakhand Pey Jal Nigam (UPJN) for capital works and Uttarakhand Jal Sansthan 
(UJS)  for  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M),  which  operate  under  the  Drinking  Water 
Department  (DDW).  The  issues  contributing  to  the  poor  performance  in  WSS  service  delivery 
are  (i)  overlapping  functioning  of  the  two  utilities,  despite  their  intended  distinct  mandates;  (ii) 
lack  of  separation  of  policy,  regulation,  and  service  delivery;  (iii)  lack  of  separation  of

Lessons Learned. ADB’s past experience in the urban sector in India reveals the issues 
of  (i)  the  inherently  complex  nature  of  urban  development  projects  which  require  great 
coordination  among  concerned  agencies  and  strong  project  management  and  implementation

Planned  and  Integrated  Approach  to  City  Development.  The  design  of  the 
Investment Program follows a planned approach. The identification of the long-term investment 
requirements and the design of the Investment Program and subprojects are based on growth 
strategies,  city  development  and  land-use  plans,  town  development  reports,  and infrastructure 
master plans. The Investment Program is also based on the principle of the integrated provision 
of  various  urban  infrastructure  and  services  to  maximize  the  benefits  from  individual  sector 
improvements.

Sector  Participation.  An  important  feature  of  the  Investment  Program  is  its  support  to  the 
Uttarakhand  government’s  urban  reform  action  plan  for  efficient,  sustainable,  inclusive,  and 
accountable service delivery. This is to be achieved through supporting (i) the decentralization 
agenda  of  the  Uttarakhand  government  and  strengthening  the  capacities  of  ULBs;  (ii) 
development  of  efficient,  accountable,  and  sustainable  service  delivery;  and  (iii)  creating 
sustainable sources of revenue through rationalization of service charges and taxes.

and  private-sector  representatives  was  conducted  on  viable  options  for  PSP  in  urban

58. 
The proposed Investment Program will be implemented over a period of 8 years (2008–

works in 2008. The sequencing of tranches has been based on a number of principles, including 
(i) readiness of subprojects in terms of institutional capacities and safeguard compliance, e.g., 
land  acquisition  and  resettlement  and  environmental  aspects;  (ii)  relative  investment  priorities 
under  the  Investment  Program,  which  ranks  the  subprojects  for  efficiency  improvements  of 
existing  utility  systems  and  capacity  development  of  service  providers  higher  than  system 
expansions; and (iii) size, growth rates, and economic potential of towns which together indicate 
the relative level of priority for investments.

within  both  UPJN  and  UJS  need  to  be  substantially  improved  for  effective  functioning. 
Necessary skill upgrading of human resources to manage WSS planning, execution, and O&M 
is  crucial,  and  organizational  and  capability  skills  have  to  be  upgraded.  To  achieve  certain 
targets  in  line  with  the  JNNURM  reform  agenda,  the  following  measures  are  essential:  (i)  the 
introduction  of  information  technology  and  technological  and  managerial  innovations,  (ii) 
improving the capacity of field staff for improved assessment and control over unaccounted for 
water  (bulk  and  consumer  metering),  and  (iii)  improving  billing  and  collection  efficiencies 
through  e-governance  and  introducing  and  adjusting  periodic  volumetric  water  and  sewerage 
tariffs. Lastly, a realistic assessment of the establishment cost and other expenditure of UPJN 
and UJS is called for, and appropriate adjustments are required.  
 
15.  With  regard  to  improvements  in  financial  capabilities,  action  is  needed  in  both 
organizations  (UPJN  and  UJS)  and  the  ULBs.  Improvements  in  financial  capabilities  are 
required  both  in  financial  management  and  in  all  accounting  system  and  practices.  While  the 
two  institutions  already  have  accrual-based  accounting,  there  are  still  improvements  which 
could  be  made  in  the  actual  use  of  the  management  accounting  tools  for  performance 
evaluation. UPJN’s accounts do not have urban and rural separation and there is definite need 
for  clearer  monitoring  of  project  accounts.  Though  UJS  does  seem  to  be  moving  towards 
computerized  billing  and  automation  of  other  functions,  the  impact  is  yet  to  be  seen.  The 
National Informatics Center-supported computerization of UJS is to be completed within a fixed 
time frame.  
 
16. 
Accountability and Performance Enhancement through Contractual Arrangement. 
The  present  system  of  subsidy  in  urban  WSS  requires  change  to  encourage  innovation  and 
accountability  and  reward  performance  improvement.  The  option  of  replacing  the  present 
subsidy  regime  with  performance-based  aid  provides  a  better  alternative  for  urban  WSS.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in India (Uttarakhand):  
 
Uttarakhand has a total population of 8.04 million people, of which 2.18 million are in urban areas (Census 
2001). The urbanization level in the state is 25.5% of the total population in the 2001 census, slightly lower 
than the national average of 27.8%. The urban growth rate of 3.1% exceeds the rural growth rate, which is 
less than 2%. With the high urban growth rates projected to further increase over time, it is expected that 
the  level  of  urbanization  will  be  37%  by  2026—which  places  the  state  as  the  seventh-most  urbanized  in 
India. The rapid urbanization, a large transient population composed of pilgrims and tourists, and lagging 
infrastructure spending places pressure on urban infrastructure. While 80% of the population has access to 
piped water supply (compared with the national access to improved water sources of 75% in 2005), service 
levels  are  poor  with  water  available  for  only  2–4  hours  per  day  at  erratic  pressures.  Per  capita  supply  is 
only  70  liters  per  day.  In  the  absence  of  water  testing  laboratories,  the  water  supply  quality  is  mostly 
unknown. Only 20 towns have sewage treatment facilities and in these towns coverage is only about 50% 
of the urban population. There are no efficient solid-waste management systems in any of the towns.  
 
Uttarakhand  is  classified  as  one  of  the  country’s  economically  stagnant  states,  where  overall  poverty  is 
over  33%.1  The  urban  population  living  in  slums2  accounts  for  about  17%  of  the  total  state  urban 
population. About 43% of the slums are located on urban fringes and 53% along drains.3 The urban poor’s 
access to basic urban infrastructure is limited, with only 71.4% of the slums covered by piped potable water 
supply,  and  only  42.8%  having  access  to  proper  sanitation  facilities.  These  create  unfavorable 
environmental conditions for poor people, and these threaten public health and reflect the multidimensional 
nature of urban poverty. 
 
The Investment Program is expected to address basic deficiencies across the state and increase economic 
growth potential through improved urban services. Direct benefits will be sustained improvements in basic 
services in all Investment Program areas. The Investment Program will have positive impacts on the poor. 
Safe drinking water is a basic need, which a significant number of poor people in Uttarakhand do not have 
access to. The burden of water collection on vulnerable segments of the population, such as women, will 
be  reduced.  Improvements  in  water  supply  quantity  and  quality,  sewerage  and  sewage  treatment,  and 
municipal solid-waste management will lead to public health improvements. This will result in reductions in 
the burden of diseases, treatment cost, and productivity losses, the impacts of which are disproportionately 
experienced  by  poor  people.  Slum  upgrading  subprojects  are  directly  targeted  at  improving  basic 
infrastructure  in  poor areas.  This  includes  improvements  in  access  roads and community  roads  including 
drainage improvement and street lighting, provision of bulk water supply and sewerage mains at the entry 
of  slum  areas,  and  support  for  enabling  a  sustainable  environment  for  improving  basic  infrastructures  in 
slums through policy development. The benefits are expected to be economic growth and direct temporary 
employment in construction work under the Investment Program.

The  Investment  Program  will  support  the  Government  of  India  and  the  Uttarakhand 
government  in  their  policy  of  balanced  regional  socioeconomic  development  and  poverty 
reduction  through  improvements  in  urban  governance,  management,  and  infrastructure  and

water supply; (ii) sewerage and sewage treatment; (iii) municipal solid-waste management; (iv) 
urban  roads  and  traffic  management;  (v)  slum  upgrading  and  poverty  reduction;  and  (vi) 
planning  and  design,  institutional  and  policy  development,  capacity  development,  and 
awareness raising.

9. 
An ESMC will be set up within the IPMU to address Investment Program environmental 
and social issues, and will be staffed by an environmental specialist and a social development

internal  monitoring.  The  design  and  supervision  consultants  will  have  resettlement  specialists

10. 
Resettlement  plans  were  prepared  in  consultation  with  stakeholders.  Consultations 
employing various methods (household sample surveys with 4,000 respondents, and two-stage 
consultation workshops and discussion with the line agencies and other stakeholders with 462 
participants)  were  conducted  during  program  preparation  (May–August  2006).  Informal 
consultations  at  the  sample  subproject  sites  involving  the  public  as  well  as  NGOs  were  also 
conducted in November 2006 and March 2007, to understand needs and preferences for basic 
infrastructure facilities, and social and environmental issues in order to reflect these in program 
design.  Consultations  were  again  undertaken  in  June  2007  involving  62  stakeholders  from 
Dehradun, Haridwar, and Nainital to disclose and discuss safeguards documents.  
 
11. 
Future  subprojects  will  also  ensure  all  stakeholders  are  involved  through  focus-group 
discussions,  socioeconomic  surveys,  and  stakeholder  consultation  meetings.  Each will  include 
records  of  public  consultation  including  issues  raised  and  how  these  were  reflected  in 
subproject  resettlement  planning.  Resettlement  planning  documents  will  be  made  available  in 
relevant local government agencies in each town, IPIU, and the IPMU offices; RPs will be made 
available in the local language. Finalized RPs will also be posted on ADB’s website. Information 
dissemination and consultation will continue throughout Investment Program implementation. 
 
12. 
Grievances of affected persons will first be brought to the attention of the implementing 
NGO  or  ESMC.  Grievances  not  redressed  by  the  NGO  will  be  brought  to  the  town-level 
committees set up to monitor Project implementation in each town. The town-level committee, 
acting  as  a  grievance  redress  committee  is  chaired  by  the  mayor  or  other  chairperson,  with 
representatives  to  include  ward  members,  the  district  magistrate,  collector,  commissioner, 
special  area  development  authority,  Uttarakhand  Pey  Jal  Nigam  (UPJN),  Uttarakhand  Jal 
Shanstan (UJS), Public Works Department (PWD), business, and civil society. As a grievance 
redress committee, the town-level committee will meet every month (if grievances are brought to 
the committee), determine the merit of each grievance, and resolve grievances within a month 
of receiving the complaint, failing which the grievance will be addressed by the general body.7 
Further grievances will be referred by APs to the appropriate courts of law. Records will be kept 
of  all  grievances  received  including  contact  details  of  complainant,  date  the  complaint  was 
received, nature of grievance, agreed corrective actions and the date these were effected, and 
final outcome.

The  Investment  Program  will  support  the  Government  of  India  and  the  Uttarakhand

2. 
The  Investment  Program  is  designed  to  improve  environmental  quality  and  living

management  works;  (v)  reduced  exposure  to  suspended  particulates  and  noise  pollution,  and
